title: Contributing to cryptoQuotes
text: Fork package clone onto computer. haven’t done , recommend using usethis::create_from_github("serkor1/cryptoQuotes", fork = TRUE). Install development dependencies devtools::install_dev_deps(), make sure package passes R CMD check running devtools::check(). R CMD check doesn’t pass cleanly, ’s good idea ask help continuing. Create Git branch pull request (PR). recommend using usethis::pr_init("brief-description--change"). Make changes, commit git, create PR running usethis::pr_push(), following prompts browser. title PR briefly describe change. body PR contain Fixes #issue-number. user-facing changes, add bullet top NEWS.md (.e. just first header). Follow style described https://style.tidyverse.org/news.html.

title: Contributing to cryptoQuotes
text: New code follow tidyverse style guide. can use styler package apply styles, please don’t restyle code nothing PR. use roxygen2, Markdown syntax, documentation. use testthat unit tests. Contributions test cases included easier accept.

title: Cryptocurrency Market Data in R
text: One sentiment indicator Bitcoin long-short ratio, can retrieved using get_lsratio()-function, Hourly Bitcoin OHLC-V data
code: ## Get the ## long-short ratio of  ## Bitcoin on the hourly LS_BTC <- get_lsratio(   ticker  = "PF_XBTUSD",   source  = "kraken",   interval = "1h",   from = Sys.Date() - 1 )

title: Cryptocurrency Market Data in R
text: limit amount market data can extracted one call. Kraken exchange, example, limit 720 rows data per call spot market, need data , need multiple calls. One solution following, Note: indepth analysis various limitations workarounds please see cryptoQuotes wiki Github
code: ## Get the SPOT ## market for over  ## 2000 rows nrow(   BTC <- get_quote(     ticker  = "BTCUSD",     source  = "kraken",     futures = FALSE,     interval = "30m",     from = Sys.Date() - 30,     to   = Sys.Date()   ) ) ## [1] 720 ## 1) create date ## sequence dates <- seq(   from = as.POSIXct(Sys.Date()),   by = "-30 mins",   length.out = 1440 )  ## 2) split the sequence ## in multiples of 100 ## by assigning numbers ## to each indices of 100 idx <- rep(   x = 1:2,   each = 720 )  ## 3) use the idx to split ## the dates into equal parts split_dates <- split(   x = dates,   f = idx )  ## 4) collect all all ## calls in a list ## using lapply ohlc <- lapply(   X = split_dates,   FUN = function(dates){               Sys.sleep(1)          cryptoQuotes::get_quote(       ticker = "BTCUSD",       source = "kraken",       futures = FALSE,       interval = "30m",       from = min(dates),       to   = max(dates)     )        })  ## 4.1) rbind all ## elements nrow(   ohlc <- do.call(     what = rbind,      args = ohlc   ) ) ## [1] 740

title: Interactive Cryptocurrency Charts in R
text: two main price charts. Japanese candlestick chart, kline(), basic OHLC chart, ohlc(), charts. chart wrapped chart()-function. charts comes volume bollinger bands default.

title: Interactive Cryptocurrency Charts in R
code: ## chart BTC ## with candlesticks chart(   ticker = BTC,   main   = kline() )

title: Interactive Cryptocurrency Charts in R
text: chart()-function comes various options color deficiency themes. Use ?chart details.
code: ## chart BTC ## with candlesticks chart(   ticker = BTC,   main   = ohlc() )

title: Interactive Cryptocurrency Charts in R
text: charts supports various indicators RSI, MACD MA. can passed respective arguments follows,
code: ## chart BTC ## with candlesticks ## and various indicators chart(   ticker = BTC,   main   = kline(),   sub    = list(     volume(),     rsi(),     macd()   ),   indicator = list(     sma(n = 7),     sma(n = 21),     bollinger_bands()   ) )

title: Interactive Cryptocurrency Charts in R
text: charts supports passing event_data, type data.frame, can plotted chart. example plotting crossing MA, Based cross indicator, BTC pair can now subset, processed accordingly. Finally, crosses can plotted using chart() addEvents() functions, like ,
code: ## Calculate moving averages ## SMA(7) and SMA(10) BTC$short_SMA <- TTR::SMA(   x = BTC$close,   n = 7 )  BTC$long_SMA <- TTR::SMA(   x = BTC$close,   n = 21 )  ## Determine the cross ## from below BTC$cross <- as.numeric(   lag(BTC$short_SMA) < BTC$long_SMA &     BTC$short_SMA > BTC$long_SMA  ) ## create event data ## and store it as a data.rfrae event_data <- subset(   BTC,   cross == 1 )  # 1.1) Extract the index # from the event data index <- zoo::index(   event_data )  # 1.2) Convert the coredata # into a data.frame event_data <- as.data.frame(   zoo::coredata(event_data) )  # 1.3) Add the index into the data.frame # case insensitive event_data$index <- index   # 1.4) add events to the data. # here we use Buys and Sells. event_data$event <- 'Bull Cross' event_data$color <- 'darkgray' ## add the events ## the chart, along ## with Moving averages ## and the Bollinger Bands ## in a candlestick chart chart(   ticker = BTC,   main   = kline(),   indicator = list(     bollinger_bands(),     sma(n = 7),     sma(n = 21)   ),   event_data = event_data )

what: Converting xts and zoo to tibble
title: Converting XTS and ZOO objects
text: Converting tibble requires steps achieve data structure xts,
code: # 1) load pipe library(magrittr)  # 2) convert to tibble # using as_tibble tbl <- tibble::as_tibble(   x = cbind(     Index = zoo::index(ATOM),     zoo::coredata(ATOM)   ) ) %>% dplyr::mutate(   Index = lubridate::as_datetime(     Index   ) )  # 3) head data head(tbl, 3) ## # A tibble: 3 × 6 ##   Index                Open  High   Low Close Volume ##   <dttm>              <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl> ## 1 2023-12-29 23:00:00  10.9  10.9  10.9  10.9 16538. ## 2 2023-12-29 23:15:00  10.9  11.0  10.9  11.0 19347. ## 3 2023-12-29 23:30:00  10.9  11.0  10.9  11.0 30591.

what: Converting xts and zoo to data.table
title: Converting XTS and ZOO objects
text: Converting data.table straightforward .data.table() handles everything hood,
code: # 1) convert to data.table # using as.data.table DT <- data.table::as.data.table(   ATOM )   # 2) set column name to upper colnames(DT)[1] <- 'Index'  # 3) head data head(DT, 3) ##                  Index   Open   High    Low  Close   Volume ##                 <POSc>  <num>  <num>  <num>  <num>    <num> ## 1: 2023-12-30 00:00:00 10.879 10.912 10.878 10.905 16538.04 ## 2: 2023-12-30 00:15:00 10.906 10.957 10.905 10.950 19347.09 ## 3: 2023-12-30 00:30:00 10.949 10.994 10.939 10.985 30590.82

title: Converting XTS and ZOO objects
text: important date.time converted different timezone process, without explicitly coding ,
code: # 1) store date.time objects time_objects <- list(   tbl = tbl$Index,   DT  = DT$Index )  # 2) check if they are all equal all(   sapply(     time_objects,     function(x) {              setequal(         x = x,         y = zoo::index(ATOM)         )            }   ) ) ## [1] TRUE

title: Converting XTS and ZOO objects
text: goes without saying R-functions wouldn’t tamper order data conversion without warning documentation, nonetheless sake argument, check OHLCV values,
code: # 1) store price objects # Open price here open_price <- list(   tbl = tbl$Open,   DT  = DT$Open )  # 2) check if they are all equal all(   sapply(     open_price,     function(x) {              setequal(         x = x,         y = ATOM$Open         )            }   ) ) ## [1] TRUE

title: Converting XTS and ZOO objects
text: Even though numerical operations xts-objects lightning fast (12% faster data.table), comes cost; doesn’t support factors characters. Converting xts-object simple trivial process, simplifies grouped operations verbose manner.

title: Cryptocurrency Market Data with quantmod and TTR
text: BTC can passed charting functions, used quantmod::tradeModel()-functions.

title: Cryptocurrency Market Data with quantmod and TTR
text: example use quantmod::tradeModel BTC,
code: ## 1) specify ## the model BTC_model <-  quantmod::specifyModel(   quantmod::Next(quantmod::OpCl(BTC)) ~ quantmod::Lag(quantmod::OpHi(BTC),0:3)   ) #> Warning: Using formula(x) is deprecated when x is a character vector of length > 1. #>   Consider formula(paste(x, collapse = " ")) instead.  ## 2) build the ## model built_model <-  quantmod::buildModel(   x = BTC_model,   method ='lm',   training.per = range(head(zoo::index(BTC), 10))   )  ## 3) trade the model quantmod::tradeModel(built_model,leverage=2) #>  #>   Model:  lm1710250254.41886  #>  #>   C.A.G.R.:  18.77%  H.P.R.:  4.18%  #>  #>   Returns by period summary: #>  #>              weekly monthly quarterly yearly #>     Max.     25.77%  38.69%    23.03% 23.03% #>     3rd Qu.   7.55%  20.29%    23.03% 23.03% #>     Mean      2.78%   9.21%    23.03% 23.03% #>     Median   -0.18%   1.88%    23.03% 23.03% #>     2rd Qu.  -4.21%  -5.52%    23.03% 23.03% #>     Min.    -14.61% -12.93%    23.03% 23.03% #>  #>   Period to date returns: #>  #>              weekly monthly quarterly yearly #>               9.47%  38.69%    23.03% 23.03%

title: cryptoQuotes: Cryptocurrency Market Data in R
text: high-level API-client provides open access cryptocurrency market data without relying low-level coding API-keys. Currently actively traded cryptocurrencies either binance, bybit, bitmart, kucoin kraken available. vignette explore case study showcase capabilities cryptoQuotes-package; Dogecoin-market react Elon Musks following tweet, Tweet Elon Musk - timezone CET.

title: cryptoQuotes: Cryptocurrency Market Data in R
text: Elon Musk tweeted (Well, now X’ed) Dogecoin January 14, 06.18 (UTC) - Dogecoin rallied. determine fast markets reacted tweets, get market data Dogecoin 1 minute intervals day tweeeted using getQuotes(), returns object class xts zoo 61 rows. calculate rally within first minute tweet, can use xts-syntax determine much rallied, Dogecoin rallied -0.15% within minute Elon Musk tweeted.
code: ## DOGEUSDT the day ## of the tweet on the ## 1m chart DOGE <- cryptoQuotes::get_quote(   ticker   = 'DOGE-USDT',   interval = '1m',   source   = 'kucoin',   futures  = FALSE,   from     = '2022-01-14 07:00:00',   to       = '2022-01-14 08:00:00' ) ## extrat the ## tweet moment tweet_moment <- DOGE["2022-01-14 07:18:00"]  ## calculate  ## rally cat(   "Doge closed:", round((tweet_moment$close/tweet_moment$open - 1),4) * 100, "%" ) #> Doge closed: -0.15 %

title: cryptoQuotes: Cryptocurrency Market Data in R
text: can illustrate candlestick charts using chart()- kline()-function,
code: ## chart the ## price action ## using klines cryptoQuotes::chart(   ticker     = DOGE,   main       = cryptoQuotes::kline(),   sub  = list(     cryptoQuotes::volume()   ),   options = list(     dark = FALSE   ) )

what: Charting price action with event lines
title: cryptoQuotes: Cryptocurrency Market Data in R
text: create , presumably, better visual overview can add event lines using event_data-argument, takes data.frame kind argument, event data, can passed chart follows,
code: ## 1) create event data.frame ## by subsetting the data event_data <- as.data.frame(   zoo::coredata(     DOGE["2022-01-14 07:18:00"]   ) )  ## 1.1) add the index  ## to the event_data event_data$index <- zoo::index(   DOGE["2022-01-14 07:18:00"] )  # 1.2) add event label # to the data event_data$event <- 'Elon Musk Tweets'  # 1.3) add color to the # event label event_data$color <- 'steelblue' ## 1) create event data.frame ## by subsetting the data event_data <- as.data.frame(   zoo::coredata(     DOGE["2022-01-14 07:18:00"]   ) )  ## 1.1) add the index  ## to the event_data event_data$index <- zoo::index(   DOGE["2022-01-14 07:18:00"] )  # 1.2) add event label # to the data event_data$event <- 'Elon Musk Tweets'  # 1.3) add color to the # event label event_data$color <- 'steelblue'  ## 1) chart the ## price action ## using klines cryptoQuotes::chart(   ticker     = DOGE,   event_data = event_data,   main       = cryptoQuotes::kline(),   sub  = list(     cryptoQuotes::volume()   ),   options = list(     dark = FALSE   ) )

title: Cryptocurrency with R

title: Assert truthfulness of conditions before evaluation — assert
code: # script: Assert truthfullness # of functions # date: 2024-02-22 # author: Serkan Korkmaz, serkor1@duck.com # objective: Demonstrate the use of the error-function. This is # mainly for contributers, and for my future self on how to use # this function properly # # # NOTE: As these are wrapped in try # they are not properly formatted. # script start;   # 1) unnamed assert # expressions foo <- function(     a,     b) {    # assert without   # named expressions   cryptoQuotes:::assert(     is.numeric(a),     is.numeric(b)   )    a + b  }  # 1.1) returns # the regular R error # messages in cli-format try(   foo(     a = "1",     b = "2"   ) ) #> Error in pkgdown::build_site_github_pages(new_process = FALSE, install = FALSE) :  #>   is.numeric(a) is not TRUE    # 2) named assert # expressions foo <- function(     a,     b) {    cryptoQuotes:::assert(     "{.arg a} is not {.cls numeric}" =  is.numeric(a),     "{.arg a} is not {.cls numeric}" = is.numeric(b)   )     a + b  }  # 2.2) Returns # custom error-messages # in cli-format try(   foo(     a = "1",     b = "2"   ) ) #> Error in pkgdown::build_site_github_pages(new_process = FALSE, install = FALSE) :  #>   ✖ `a` is not <numeric>   # 3) custom error # messages on foo <- function(     a) {    cryptoQuotes:::assert(     is.numeric(a),     error_message = sprintf(       fmt = "{.val %s} is not a numeric value.",       a     )   )    a  }  # 2.2) Returns # custom error-messages with # passed values in cli-format try(   foo(     a = "1"   ) ) #> Error in pkgdown::build_site_github_pages(new_process = FALSE, install = FALSE) :  #>   "1" is not a numeric value.      # script end;

title: calibrate the time window of a list of xts objects — calibrate_window
text: Returns xts object.

title: calibrate the time window of a list of xts objects — calibrate_window
code: # script: scr_FUN # date: 2023-12-27 # author: Serkan Korkmaz, serkor1@duck.com # objective: Demonstrate the use of the convinience # funtions # script start;  # by default the Fear and Greed Index # is given daily. So to align these values # with, say, weekly candles it has to be aggregated # # In this example the built-in data are used  # 1) check index of BTCUSDT and # the Fear and Greed Index setequal(   zoo::index(BTC),   zoo::index(FGIndex) ) #> [1] FALSE  # 2) to align the indices, # we use the convincience functions # by splitting the FGI by the BTC index. FGIndex <- split_window(   xts = FGIndex,   by  = zoo::index(BTC),    # Remove upper bounds of the   # index to avoid overlap between   # the dates.   #   # This ensures that the FGI is split   # according to start of each weekly   # BTC candle   bounds = 'upper' )  # 3) as splitWindow returns a list # it needs to passed into calibrateWindow # to ensure comparability FGIndex <- calibrate_window(   list = FGIndex,    # As each element in the list can include   # more than one row, each element needs to be aggregated   # or summarised.   #   # using xts::first gives the first element   # of each list, along with its values   FUN  = xts::first )   # 3) check if candles aligns # accordingly setequal(   zoo::index(BTC),   zoo::index(FGIndex) ) #> [1] TRUE   # As the dates are now aligned # and the Fear and Greed Index being summarised by # the first value, the Fear and Greed Index is the opening # Fear and Greed Index value, at each candle.  # script end;

title:

code: # script: scr_FUN # date: 2023-12-27 # author: Serkan Korkmaz, serkor1@duck.com # objective: Demonstrate the use of the convinience # funtions # script start;  # by default the Fear and Greed Index # is given daily. So to align these values # with, say, weekly candles it has to be aggregated # # In this example the built-in data are used  # 1) check index of BTCUSDT and # the Fear and Greed Index setequal(   zoo::index(BTC),   zoo::index(FGIndex) ) #> [1] FALSE  # 2) to align the indices, # we use the convincience functions # by splitting the FGI by the BTC index. FGIndex <- split_window(   xts = FGIndex,   by  = zoo::index(BTC),    # Remove upper bounds of the   # index to avoid overlap between   # the dates.   #   # This ensures that the FGI is split   # according to start of each weekly   # BTC candle   bounds = 'upper' )  # 3) as splitWindow returns a list # it needs to passed into calibrateWindow # to ensure comparability FGIndex <- calibrate_window(   list = FGIndex,    # As each element in the list can include   # more than one row, each element needs to be aggregated   # or summarised.   #   # using xts::first gives the first element   # of each list, along with its values   FUN  = xts::first )   # 3) check if candles aligns # accordingly setequal(   zoo::index(BTC),   zoo::index(FGIndex) ) #> [1] TRUE   # As the dates are now aligned # and the Fear and Greed Index being summarised by # the first value, the Fear and Greed Index is the opening # Fear and Greed Index value, at each candle.  # script end;

title: split xts object iteratively in lists of desired intervals — split_window
code: # script: scr_FUN # date: 2023-12-27 # author: Serkan Korkmaz, serkor1@duck.com # objective: Demonstrate the use of the convinience # funtions # script start;  # by default the Fear and Greed Index # is given daily. So to align these values # with, say, weekly candles it has to be aggregated # # In this example the built-in data are used  # 1) check index of BTCUSDT and # the Fear and Greed Index setequal(   zoo::index(BTC),   zoo::index(FGIndex) ) #> [1] FALSE  # 2) to align the indices, # we use the convincience functions # by splitting the FGI by the BTC index. FGIndex <- split_window(   xts = FGIndex,   by  = zoo::index(BTC),    # Remove upper bounds of the   # index to avoid overlap between   # the dates.   #   # This ensures that the FGI is split   # according to start of each weekly   # BTC candle   bounds = 'upper' )  # 3) as splitWindow returns a list # it needs to passed into calibrateWindow # to ensure comparability FGIndex <- calibrate_window(   list = FGIndex,    # As each element in the list can include   # more than one row, each element needs to be aggregated   # or summarised.   #   # using xts::first gives the first element   # of each list, along with its values   FUN  = xts::first )   # 3) check if candles aligns # accordingly setequal(   zoo::index(BTC),   zoo::index(FGIndex) ) #> [1] TRUE   # As the dates are now aligned # and the Fear and Greed Index being summarised by # the first value, the Fear and Greed Index is the opening # Fear and Greed Index value, at each candle.  # script end;
